briefdescription.para: Stringify a macro after expansion.
Stringify a macro argument.
Maximum length of filenames that are generated by our programs.

detaileddescription.para: This definition should be used throughout the complete ViennaRNA package wherever a static array holding filenames of output files is declared.

briefdescription.para: Maximum length of id taken from fasta header for filename generation.

detaileddescription.para: this has to be smaller than FILENAME_MAX_LENGTH since in most cases, some suffix will be appended to the ID

briefdescription.para: Trim only characters leading the string.
Trim only characters trailing the string.
Trim only characters within the string.
Replace remaining characters after trimming with the first delimiter in list.
Default settings for trimming, i.e. trim leading and trailing.
Trim characters anywhere in the string.
Safely create a formatted string.

detaileddescription.para: This function is a safe implementation for creating a formatted character array, similar to sprintf. Internally, it uses the asprintf function if available to dynamically allocate a large enough character array to store the supplied content. If asprintf is not available, mimic it's behavior using vsnprintf.

simplesect.para: The returned pointer of this function should always be passed to free() to release the allocated memory
vrna_strdup_vprintf(), vrna_strcat_printf()

parameterdescription.para: The list of variables used to fill the format string

simplesect.para: The formatted, null-terminated string, or NULL if something has gone wrong

briefdescription.para: Safely create a formatted string.

detaileddescription.para: This function is the va_list version of vrna_strdup_printf()

simplesect.para: The returned pointer of this function should always be passed to free() to release the allocated memory
vrna_strdup_printf(), vrna_strcat_printf(), vrna_strcat_vprintf()

parameterdescription.para: The list of arguments to fill the format string

simplesect.para: The formatted, null-terminated string, or NULL if something has gone wrong

briefdescription.para: Safely append a formatted string to another string.

detaileddescription.para: This function is a safe implementation for appending a formatted character array, similar to a cobination of strcat and sprintf. The function automatically allocates enough memory to store both, the previous content stored at dest and the appended format string. If the dest pointer is NULL, the function allocate memory only for the format string. The function returns the number of characters in the resulting string or -1 in case of an error.

simplesect.para: vrna_strcat_vprintf(), vrna_strdup_printf(), vrna_strdup_vprintf()

parameterdescription.para: The address of a char *pointer where the formatted string is to be appended
The list of variables used to fill the format string

simplesect.para: The number of characters in the final string, or -1 on error

briefdescription.para: Safely append a formatted string to another string.

detaileddescription.para: This function is the va_list version of vrna_strcat_printf()

simplesect.para: vrna_strcat_printf(), vrna_strdup_printf(), vrna_strdup_vprintf()

parameterdescription.para: The address of a char *pointer where the formatted string is to be appended
The list of argument to fill the format string

simplesect.para: The number of characters in the final string, or -1 on error

memberdef.argsstring: (char *string, const char *delimiters, unsigned int keep, unsigned int options)
memberdef.name: vrna_strtrim

briefdescription.para: Trim a string by removing (multiple) occurences of a particular character.

detaileddescription.para: This function removes (multiple) consecutive occurences of a set of characters (delimiters) within an input string. It may be used to remove leading and/or trailing whitespaces or to restrict the maximum number of consecutive occurences of the delimiting characters delimiters. Setting keep=0 removes all occurences, while other values reduce multiple consecutive occurences to at most keep delimiters. This might be useful if one would like to reduce multiple whitespaces to a single one, or to remove empty fields within a comma-separated value string.

The parameter delimiters may be a pointer to a 0-terminated char string containing a set of any ASCII character. If NULL is passed as delimiter set or an empty char string, all whitespace characters are trimmed. The options parameter is a bit vector that specifies which part of the string should undergo trimming. The implementation distinguishes the leading (VRNA_TRIM_LEADING), trailing (VRNA_TRIM_TRAILING), and in-between (VRNA_TRIM_IN_BETWEEN) part with respect to the delimiter set. Combinations of these parts can be specified by using logical-or operator.

simplesect.para: The delimiter always consists of a single character from the set of characters provided. In case of alternative delimiters and non-null keep parameter, the first keep delimiters are preserved within the string. Use VRNA_TRIM_SUBST_BY_FIRST to substitute all remaining delimiting characters with the first from the delimiters list.
VRNA_TRIM_LEADING, VRNA_TRIM_TRAILING, VRNA_TRIM_IN_BETWEEN, VRNA_TRIM_SUBST_BY_FIRST, VRNA_TRIM_DEFAULT, VRNA_TRIM_ALL

parameterdescription.para: The delimiter characters as 0-terminated char array (or NULL)
The maximum number of consecutive occurences of the delimiter in the output string
The option bit vector specifying the mode of operation

simplesect.para: The number of delimiters removed from the string

parblock.para: Since many scripting languages treat strings as immutable objects, this function does not modify the input string directly. Instead, it returns the modified string as second return value, together with the number of removed delimiters.

The scripting language interface provides an overloaded version of this function, with default parameters delimiters=NULL, keep=0, and options=VRNA_TRIM_DEFAULT. See, e.g. embed:rst:inline:py:func:`RNA.strtrim()` in the :doc:`/api_python`.

briefdescription.para: Split a string into tokens using a delimiting character.

detaileddescription.para: This function splits a string into an array of strings using a single character that delimits the elements within the string. The default delimiter is the ampersand '&' and will be used when NULL is passed as a second argument. The returned list is NULL terminated, i.e. the last element is NULL. If the delimiter is not found, the returned list contains exactly one element: the input string.
For instance, the following code:
* GGGG * CCCC * AAAAA * and properly free's the memory occupied by the returned element array.

simplesect.para: This function internally uses strtok_r() and is therefore considered to be thread-safe. Also note, that it is the users responsibility to free the memory of the array and that of the individual element strings! In case the input string consists of consecutive delimiters, starts or ends with one or multiple delimiters, empty strings are produced in the output list, indicating the empty fields of data resulting from the split. Use vrna_strtrim() prior to a call to this function to remove any leading, trailing, or in-between empty fields.

parameterdescription.para: The input string that should be split into elements
The delimiting character. If NULL, the delimiter is "&"

simplesect.para: A NULL terminated list of the elements in the string

briefdescription.para: Create a random string using characters from a specified symbol set.

simplesect.para: A random string of length 'l' containing characters from the symbolset

briefdescription.para: Calculate hamming distance between two sequences.

simplesect.para: The hamming distance between s1 and s2

briefdescription.para: Calculate hamming distance between two sequences up to a specified length.

detaileddescription.para:
This function is similar to vrna_hamming_distance() but instead of comparing both sequences up to their actual length only the first 'n' characters are taken into account
s1
The first sequence
s2
The second sequence
n
The length of the subsequences to consider (starting from the 5' end)
The hamming distance between s1 and s2

briefdescription.para: Convert an input sequence (possibly containing DNA alphabet characters) to RNA alphabet.

detaileddescription.para: This function substitudes T and t with U and u, respectively

briefdescription.para: Convert an input sequence to uppercase.
Reverse a string in-place.

detaileddescription.para: This function reverses a character string in the form of an array of characters in-place, i.e. it changes the input parameter.

simplesect.para: After execution, the input sequence consists of the reverse string prior to the execution.

briefdescription.para: Retrieve a DNA sequence which resembles the complement of the input sequence.

detaileddescription.para: This function returns a mew DNA string which is the complement of the input, i.e. the nucleotide letters A,C,G, and T are substituted by their complements T,G,C, and A, respectively.
Any characters not belonging to the alphabet of the 4 canonical bases of DNA are not altered.

simplesect.para: This function also handles lower-case input sequences and treats U of the RNA alphabet equally to T
The complement of the input DNA sequence

briefdescription.para: Remove gap characters from a nucleotide sequence.

simplesect.para: A copy of the input sequence with all gap characters removed

briefdescription.para: Add a separating '&' character into a string according to cut-point position.

detaileddescription.para: If the cut-point position is less or equal to zero, this function just returns a copy of the provided string. Otherwise, the cut-point character is set at the corresponding position

simplesect.para: A copy of the provided string including the cut-point character

briefdescription.para: Remove a separating '&' character from a string.

detaileddescription.para: This function removes the cut-point indicating '&' character from a string and memorizes its position in a provided integer variable. If not '&' is found in the input, the integer variable is set to -1. The function returns a copy of the input string with the '&' being sliced out.

simplesect.para: A copy of the input string with the '&' being sliced out

briefdescription.para: Find (all) occurrences of a character within a string.

detaileddescription.para: string The C string to be scanned
c The character to be searched for

n The maximum number of occurences to search for (or 0 for all occurrences)
An 1-based array of positions(0-based) or NULL on error. Position 0 specifies the number of occurrences found.

briefdescription.para: Convert an input sequence to uppercase.
Convert a DNA input sequence to RNA alphabet.
Create a random string using characters from a specified symbol set.
Calculate hamming distance between two sequences.
Calculate hamming distance between two sequences up to a specified length.
General utility- and helper-functions for RNA sequence and structure strings used throughout the ViennaRNA Package.
